title: Living with Integrity
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock, they called him. Not to his face, of course. He was the general manager of the TriCorp factory on the outskirts of town. A stern man, it was said, a fair man, but utterly inflexible. Once, a new hire named Tommy had shorted a box of widgets on his production line. Instead of fifty, the box held forty-nine. Tommy, panicked, had slipped a widget from the previous run into the box to make up for it. No one would have known. But Old Man Hemlock, on a random inspection, found the slightly different widget, traced it back to Tommy, and Tommy was gone by lunch. 

That was the legend, anyway. Whether completely true or embellished over time, the story served as a stark warning: integrity mattered. Not just honesty, but a wholeness, a consistency between word and deed, a commitment to doing what's right even when no one is watching. It's easy to be virtuous when the spotlight shines; true integrity reveals itself in the shadows. 

Consider the biblical example of Daniel. A man of unwavering principle, even when faced with the threat of death in the lions' den, he remained true to his faith and to God's commands. His integrity was not situational; it was the bedrock of his character. He didn't compromise his values to gain favor or avoid hardship. 

In our own lives, integrity is not about grand gestures or heroic feats. It's about the small choices we make every day. It's about keeping our promises, even when it's inconvenient. It's about being honest in our dealings, even when we could get away with bending the truth. It's about standing up for what's right, even when it's unpopular. It's about being the same person in public and in private. These small choices, accumulated over time, define who we are. Integrity is the scaffolding upon which a life of meaning and purpose is built. Without it, our character crumbles. Cultivate it. Guard it. Let it be your guiding light, illuminating the path forward.
image_description: A sturdy, old stone bridge spanning a clear, flowing river in a forest; the bridge is overgrown with moss and vines, suggesting steadfastness through time.
insights: The story of Tommy and Old Man Hemlock is a parable of sorts. The slight deviation, the seemingly insignificant act of replacing the widget, exposed a lack of integrity. Luke 16:10 says, 'Whoever is faithful in small matters will be faithful in large ones; whoever is dishonest in small matters will be dishonest in large ones.' Integrity isn't a switch we can turn on and off; it's a habit we cultivate, one small decision at a time. The life of Daniel further demonstrates integrity in the face of adversity.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often fall short of living with true integrity. Forgive me for the times I have compromised my values, bent the truth, or failed to stand up for what is right. Help me to cultivate a spirit of honesty, consistency, and commitment to doing what is right, even when it's difficult. Grant me the courage to live with integrity in all areas of my life, so that my words and actions may be a reflection of Your truth and love. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Where in your life are you tempted to compromise your integrity? What small choices can you make today to strengthen your commitment to doing what is right? How can you be more mindful of aligning your words and actions with your values?
